Posted: October 30, 2015
												While fun at first, the game quickly turns into a chore. The game lacks variety in the enemy designs, and runs on the same 2 enemy variations until Act 4, which is about 6 hours in the game. Level design is confusing, shaped like a Maze and as a result you will spend a considerable ammount of time backtracking to find a particular shop or door. A few puzzles are placed here and there to break the grind, but those demand patience rather than cunning (ex. alternating spike traps).The game isn't bad, but it's not good either. Even for a hacknslash, it's overly repetitive, and I just can't find a reedeming quality that would make me play it again. It doesn't have the depth of a dungeon crawler, neither the replayability of a Roguelike.Perhaps the modding community will be the saving grace for this title, but ultimately the original product is not convincing.

Posted: April 9, 2016
												I was skeptical of this game at first - I'm a fan of pixel graphics, but the bullet hell aspect of it seemed to lack depth from the previews and screen shots. I was very wrong  about that- the bosses and regular minions are challenging and take a lot of strategy (mainly the bosses) and learning of their attack patterns to defeat (some bosses are downright impossible without teammates and change up their patterns a lot, but they're beatable alone once you find a strategy that works). The skills for each class fit each class nicely and make each class play very, very differently, which is great for variety and the team aspect of the game. These skills allow you to grow you character as you see fit; you can do more damage, do that damage more often or upgrade/purchase unique skills, or buy skills that allow you to be more durable in different ways. These skills play to each class' particular strengths, and as a result, they are all pretty balanced, but there are also weaknesses that can be overcome with time or teammates. It's a simple setup and skill tree, and it works extremely well for character balance.The music is nice, but I ended up turning it off in favor of my own playlist, but aside from that, there really are no discernable negatives to this game. I think this game was made by gamers, for gamers, and incorporates a lot of good ideas into a very streamlined, good product.Highly recommend.

Posted: March 7, 2016
												It's fun and it's challenging. I live in Germany, my friends live in Finland and we haven't had any major problems with the netcode, works as easy as a plug and play.A fair warning though, if you play together with your friends, you take a big risk letting other players in your game. They can drain all your lives which are shared. Last time we played, we couldn't finish level 1 because one random player made it quite challenging by dying 3 times in the first 2 rooms. The miniboss monsters also get stuck quite often on corners while rushing head-on, the bigger round and wormy things. Those are the cons I can think of.Good casual, diabolic rpg with variety in the characters. As you are given only specific attacks for each character, you are forced to play differently. Its simple but good.And the Dev seems to be really nice :)

Posted: March 11, 2016
												One of the most entertaining pixel-art styled games I've ever played. It's good enough playing solo, but it's a helluva fun playing in coop. The classes, upgrades, monsters, bosses and "leveling" system are great, and the level design is really clever (especially those secrets, I'm really into that kind of stuff). Both the main campaign and addon are really well-made.

Posted: October 7, 2015
												I'd love to put more time into this game.  It's a great multiplayer dungeon crawler.  There are tons of secrets to be discovered.  My favorite is a puzzle that unlocks a bonus round.Each class has a distinct feel and playstyle.  Just to name a few, there's the glass cannon wizard, a high HP life-draining warlock, and a ranger - the master of ranged combat.  As you continue through the duengons, you can unlock new abilities.  Don't be put off by the warlock's starting puny dagger.  Eventually the warlock can cast devastating spells.  Just seeing what each class can do is enough to make me want to dive back into the dungeons.Since you share lives with the team (unless something changed since my last login,) it can be difficult if you have reckless teammates.  Although, when the lives runout the next player to die is essentially sidelined.  I've had some players drop the game after that, but it is possible to get more lives and resurrect dead teammates.If you're looking for an inexpensive game to play with friends, Hammerwatch is good option with a decent learning curve.  If nothing else, wishlist it and wait until the next steam sale.

Posted: March 17
												This is a fine game for people who want almost endless repetition of a very simple Gauntlet style game loop wrapped in cute pixel artistry and a cool soundtrack. If you have friends that suffer from the same illness, so much the better! Everyone else should stick to ARPGs that evolved from this type of games though.+Nostalgia trip guaranteed by graphics that for once could actually almost pass for a 16bit game...if you disable all the shader tricks of course+Same for sound effects+Fine soundtrack+If you can tolerate the repetition, there is a lot to play and the campaigns have replay value thanks to the class system+The two campaigns are almost like slightly different games-Extremely repetitive (even more than this review) and simplistic to a point where it feels almost obsolete at this point-Primary campaign is quite slow and dull. It doesn't allow revisiting previous areas after a boss fight, it drip feeds upgrades at a glacial pace, making character progress feel non-existent and the levels become too large and sprawling after the first boss to be enjoyable-Game and level design seems to be intentionally geared towards making dying unavoidable. Everything feels "hard" just for the sake of it instead of any clever idea or innovation-Too many traps that cause instant death and can't be disabled even after passing through them. This makes backtracking to look for secrets etc. rather tedious-Some enemies are very irritating to fight and have attacks that are almost invisible if you keep shader effects on-Ranged classes seem to have the edge in almost every situation compared to melee classes who have to stick their faces in fire or dance around like mad to get anything done-Too many very long moments in multiplayer where dead players have nothing to do but to watch others play in the hope finding more lives

Posted: February 12, 2014
												Experience on Linux so far:+ Resolved external dependency problem for Mono.- D-pad does not work with any of my joypads (various versions of the "PS2" joypad from Logitech)The game:While I will be the first one to condemn hipster pixel art, I'll give this game a pass. The game is fun enough for me to forget that I'm playing a 1990's looking game in 2014. The music and audio is good while retaining some old-school goodness.Hack and slash RPG with multiplayer support. This is exactly what I wanted when I was a teenager. If this had been released in the mid 90's it would have been the game of games.That said, it's not bad in 2014. In fact, it is great fun if you like old hack and slash games of Zelda-style. (not Zelda 2, obviously, this is top down)When I first tried this game the developers made an error, they had an external dependency for Mono requiring you to install that package in Ubuntu. This is not the way Steam games are supposed to work, Steam is supposed to be your repository for any special library requirements of the game. Since then the developers have fixed this issue and it now runs like any other game under Steam.While I absolutely loath C# and Mono (and deem developers who favour it as "not good"), it will not affect the score. After all, I am reviewing the game and not developer competence and it's a fun game. ps, I love good olde C.Score:3/5

Posted: January 2, 2014
												On the whole, this is a great tribue to Gauntlet style gaming.Level design:  Complex well thought out levels make you think about how to best handle a situation.  Secrets abound, but are very cleverly hidden.  You will likely miss some.  Lack of random level generation is a minus, but one could be added at a later date.Graphics:  Very nostalgic feel, but very good detail at the same time.  You even have the option to make it look like you are playing on an arcade machine or old CRT if you wish.  They did an excellent job of adding good graphics while keeping the same feel.Sound:  The music is good, but didn't really stand out to me.Gameplay:  Plays very well with a controller.  Could have been better though if you used the right analog for directional fire instead of having a hold to strafe key.  Also the campaign lacks a save feature.  This disappointed me.Multiplayer:  If a player disconnects, they can recconect right to your game starting back at the last check point.  Lives are shared however, so if one player lags and gets killed by a trap repeatedly, it could eat all of your lives quickly.  However this is made up for by the fact that money isn't split, it's duplicated for both players, allowing both to buy all the upgrades they need, including more lives.Final words:  There is a level designer you can use, but I don't see a way to share them with the community or for people to vote on them.  If there was, or if there was a map mutator for randomized level design in the options, this game would be perfect.  Still I highly reccomend this game as I like it far too much already, I couldn't stop playing.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												The perfect blend of Action with light RPG elements.The visual puzzles, maze-like corridors and hordes of enemies are quite well done though.At this point I've only played the game for a few hours but so far is appears to be the type of game that rewards the player for exploring every singles nook, cranny and corridor in the hopes of finding a secret room or hidden switch.Recommended for those who feel a bit nostalgic for the co-op action of games like Gauntlet II (which, in my opinion, still hasn't seen a ported release that tops the 4-player action of the arcade stand up).

Posted: January 2, 2014
												Gauntlet for the modern generation. Each class has multiple attacks that are gradually unlocked and upgraded to use on endless hordes of monsters.  Four unique classes, multiple difficulties, survival mode and a plethora of secrets and hidden rooms, add to the replay ability of the game.  Boss fights are engaging and include increasing mechanics as the boss's health dwindles.  Then adding four player co-op into the mix can add for a hilarious experience as you try to fight off monster after monster while avoiding traps and racing for treasure.I have spent many hours with this game and have not had any issues. If you plan to play with a controller, you will need to power it on first before launching the game, to allow it to be detected.

Posted: January 22, 2016
												Within five minutes of playing this game, I was thrown 25 years into the past.  If you were a youngin' when the NES and SNES were the thing, you'll love this game.  It's hard and doesn't mess around which is a nice change from game these days.  No tutorials, no hand holding, you're just thrown into the game and fight until you die.  And die you will.  At first the game seemed pretty shallow, but once you start upgrading your character, the real fun begins.  The best thing about this game is both local and online multi-player.  Playing this game is 23904809323 times better with friends.  A neat feature would be have friendly fire an option to turn on to make it even harder.  The only complaint I have is that using the menus with a controller is frustrating because the "tab index" is out of whack.  Great game. 10/10

Posted: January 27, 2016
												Hammerwatch is a great multiplayer game. I picked it up with some friends on sale for under $3 and we haven't looked back. It plays much like the old gauntlet games on the NES (There are even a few bonus levels that look and play like those games too) and the game offers hours of entertainment. There are tons of secrets to find in the game and plenty of classes to choose from to keep things interesting. The game also has workshop support to expand your game even further. There are lots of different mini bosses and regular bosses, offering a challenging experience. If you love dungeon crawlers or the old gauntlet games then Hammerwatch is for you.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Hammerwatch is a total gem. Whether you're playing it casually, or hardcore it's worth the 10$ purchase- but if it's on sale, there's no excuse not to keep this simple and equally deep dungeon crawl experience in your library. The chapters have different styles and enemies,  mixing up the visuals while your character gains new skills and abilities, I thought it was a real shame this game didn't have a New Game + feauture, because I would have liked to beat it again with my developed character on the hard difficulty. This game is moderate in difficulty level with worthy challenge, and the hard difficulty is infact hard, which is why I would have enjoyed progessing through it again if New Game + were available. Overall, I give it a -=8.8 // 10.0=- and HIGHLY reccomend this game.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												A great and fun to play game with nice grapshics and soundtrack. The main campaign is quite challenging, and you can also download user-made or generator-made maps. You can also play in local or internet co-op, which is a great option. Completing any dungeon with friends is easier and, most important, more fun. Overall, Hammerwatch is nice and quite challenging action-"RPG" game with co-op. The only bad point of this game is that the character progression is minimal. I've really liked this game and I'd recommend it to everybody who wants nice action game set in pixel environment or wants to have fun in co-op with friends.

Posted: December 1, 2014
												Totally delivers on the classic Guantlet feel. Possibly better than original Guantlet did!Pros: Fun times. Good challenge. Pixels done right. Surprisingly good-attitude among the players. Pretty well-fleshed out content-wise, with the classes, skills, enemies, shops, secrets... Crutches and challenges are simple, but make for some lol-able replay. Speaking of replayability, yes, it's got it - via those secrets and challenges for solo, and multiplied by randomness of multiplayer.Cons: Auto-fire isn't - pressing one button really fast is not a skill, it's not fun, it's medically damaging - ow ow ow make it stop. If you don't have an analog joystick, trying to work with 4 directions is ... extra hard and slightly less fun.

Posted: December 1, 2014
												I *highly* recommend this game for people that like oldschool RPG/Hack N Slash genre style games. You play from a top down perspective and kill as many enemies as it takes to get to the end of each level. It feels much like the old gauntlet games. You eat food/crystals to regen health or mana, gain money to upgrade your spells and abilites, and uncover in-game secrets for a chance at great rewards. You can play as a Paladin, Priest, Rogue, Warlock, Archer, or a Wizard. Levels are always the same layout each new game, but with plenty of classes and a lengthy compaign it does not disapoint as far as value goes. You can easily expect 15-25+ hours with both campaigns put together, so if you manage to find this on sale its a no-brainer as far as value is concerned. With Survival mode and plenty of workshop maps to play this game can provide even more hours. I have seen people hit around 30-80 hours before growing bored of this game.---- However, it can get slightly repetitive after long play sessions and the graphics are not exactly cutting edge. Directional targeting can be tricky as well. Online play can be a little frustrating, as people will just kick you for slight mistakes or at their convenience. (Whether you deserved it or if they just wanted to have some fun for kicking you) I suggest you host your own game if thats the case, and just let people join you. I only prefer this game with a xbox controller or equivalent gamepad in mind. PC controls get the job done though if you dont have a choice, the PC controls didnt seem like they were a huge inconvience.

												I am really enjoying Hammerwatch. It was gifted to me, but I would definitely pay $10 for it. Posted: January 7, 2015
												A simple, addicting dungeon crawler. Reminiscent of the original Gauntlet games, but with a bit more spice to it. You choose from a small selection of classes, each with their own unique attacks, abillities, and power-ups. Each class plays differently: the ranger fires arrows and lays bombs while the paladin blocks projectiles with his shield while slicing up enemies at close range, for example. The recent massive update (Temple of the Sun) added tons of class balancing and an entire new class, the priest, which suggests that more classes may come in the future (this is what I'm really hoping for, as learning all the ins and outs of the classes make the game a really fun experience). Two main campaigns will soak up a few hours of gameplay each. The game also comes with a level editor, and the Steam community has already created some really polished campaigns (some better than others, of course). So there will always be new content coming out.The game really shines with its multiplayer. I bought the 4-pack and gave the extra copies to friends, and we've been really enjoying the dungeon crawl together. Beating the first boss for the first time was a very rewarding experience. Single player is still fun, though can get a bit monotonous once you learn exactly how all the enemies respond to you and how to safely win each battle. It's more fun to have other players watchign your back or helping you pick up all the treasure. The only thing that I want from this game is more classes and more campaigns. Everything else is looking great. Definitely recommend.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												This game is a spiritual successor to the classic Gauntlet arcade game before it took a southward turn during its console years.  It's about killing hordes upon hordes of enemies in spectacular fashion and like Gauntlet, it's best enjoyed with friends.  Secret doors, hidden treasures, magic spells and abilities, and endless things to slaughter! Sound good to you?

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Hammerwatch is an excellent game! It feels great and plays a lot like an old-school hack'n'slash. It's got beautiful pixel art with great particle and shadow effects. You'll be bashing your way through hordes, and hordes of enemies to eventually fight 4 equally challenging bosses. There are various classes to pick from each feeling very unique to it's gameplay. Instead of the traditional way of progressing through the game by earning EXP you only earn gold, which you can spend on upgrades, potions and even extra lives. This really fits the game really well as you can get into situations where you may have to tactically plan your purchases, would extra damage benefit you more than an extra life? There's plenty of upgrades to unlock.The game is full of secrets, filled with great treasures and easter eggs. Even though the game isn't randomly generated it is still fun to play through the same map over and over again. This is absolutely one of my favorite games of 2013. Although the multiplayer has some problems (Hosting and you can't save games) it's still fun. The controls aren't bad and works great with mouse and keyboard! Some may have a better experience with a gamepad though.

Posted: August 15, 2013
												When it comes to a retro feel, something that reminds you of Diablo 2 or even Realm of The Mad Gods, Hammerwatch does exactly that. I followed this game from the Steam Greenlight forums and even tested the beta. From the beginning I knew that this was something I wanted to get my hands on once it came out.The game takes place inside of Castle Hammerwatch, where your goal will be to travel from down the prison up to the royal chambers in the top and kill the evil dragon. You play as either a Paladin, Wizard, Warlock or Knight and each character has its own weapon and special ability.Don’t be fooled, this is a serious game; and even on medium difficulty you will still have a hard time fighting through the numerous levels in each Act. The game is better played in multiplayer mode, but to be honest, good luck joining a game. For some reason I find it impossible to host a game, but I am able to join others, and this is when the game is best played.Hammerwatch also offers a few perks, what they call “crutches” in the game if you choose to host your own single or multiplayer game. Different options allow you to make the game easier or a little harder. I suggest playing with the HP Regen and Infinite Lives crutch on when first playing, that way you can get a feel for what you’re about to be in for.A game that is still in beta and continuously going through changes is sometimes hard to review, taking everything into consideration the game is awesome. Aside from the bunk multiplayer Hammerwatch is worth every penny. Constant battle action laced with power ups, secret passages and hidden doors makes Hammerwatch a soon to be classic and a necessity in any gamers library.Graphics: 7/10Playability: 8/10Story: 4/10Challenge: 8/10Replay Value: 6/10

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Picked this up on sale. A couple hours into this game and I already feel like I got my money's worth. I'd recommend using a controller over the keyboard - gauntlet SmashTV style fun with some fun/simple RPG elements. There are satisfying secrets & puzzles to find along the way (a benefit of non-random generated maps), plenty of save points for shorter time commitments, and neat class mechanics. I can see myself playing through the game alone, and then maybe trying a new class with some friends multiplayer.

Posted: December 20, 2014
												I'm giving this a thumbs-up where other reviewers gave it a down.  I got this from a humblebundle and wasn't focused on this at all.  After trying it out I was surprised.  The best part, I got my wife to play it and it's the first game (besides minecraft) she's enjoyed co-op enough to pick this game.  Usually she has me pick the games we play together.Overall I enjoy this game.  There are several problems that stand out to me and I wanted to mention:- The campaign maps aren't always straight forward.  Several times we've cleared an area and forgot where we need to go.  This causes you to walk a lot exploring for enemies.  (That's usually what kills a co-op session with my wife)- The Paladin is a well rounded, powerful class.  Had I known he unlocks a healing spell, my wife and I would be Paladin+Paladin instead of Paladin+Priest.- Although this is minor and very subjective... I'm not a fan of the money system for upgrades.  I would have preferred a skill tree so I could see what I'm aiming for.  Instead I looked up the skills on the wiki to create an upgrade plan.- Co-op is a requirement to fully enjoy this game.Finally I'd like to address one comment I've seen in a couple other reviews.+ Although the campaign is linear (not random or procedural), I've found that the replay-ability is fairly high because of both the diverse classes and the amount of secret areas in maps.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes Gauntlet-style games. I've had a ton of fun playing through the campaigns with friends, and we're still making our way through the great community campaigns available in the Steam Marketplace!The party-creation experience could be easier and more consistent than it is, but once you get into a game with your buddies, the fun is immediate and sustained. The various classes and available modifiers offer lots of opportunity for experimenting with different strategies, which helps to keep things fresh even after you've completed several campaigns with the same group of people.Note that while the game is playable with a keyboard all of my friends and I prefer playing this with controllers to reduce hand fatigue. We use PS3 and Xbox 360 controllers, but you can use the controller of your choice.

Posted: July 5, 2015
												Holy crap, this little game is addictive. I love everything about it: the pixel art, first of all--BEAUTIFULLY done and very cute sprites, across the boardthe graphics options are surprisingly versatile and the lighting effects are beautiful and atmosphericthe music keeps getting stuck in my head (especially the tune from the bonus levels), and the sound effects are satisfying and fit right in smoothly; usually there's at least one sound in a game that bugs me, but this is all so goodthe gameplay is simple, straightforward, and balanced. 6 classes, upgrading by purchase, plenty of loot with which to do so, and each class' special is complementary to their weaknessthe puzzles are satisfyingly challenging and great to figure out together in multiplayerThere's probably even more that could be said, but these are my favorite things about it. The only downside I can think of is that I wish the editor was easier to understand; I'll probably just have to do my own research into using it.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												The next step from the old Gauntlet games and similar hack n' slash dungeon crawlers. This game takes the essence of old-school gauntlet and perfects it. Graphics are reminiscent of yesteryear, but with current-gen effects. However, the sound design is what really stands out in my opinion. If you're playing solo, Warlock is the preferred class as the poison dagger proves useful for guerilla tactics + high HP pool + chain lightning spell.The difficulty is on-point, as it takes multiple plays to get further into the dungeon.

I do wish the dungeons were randomly generated, it does kill the replay value. I hope this ends up in the work shop for some add ons. Overall game play was solid, fun and challenging. I give it a 7.5/10. Cheers

Posted: March 8, 2015
												A very fun dungeon-crawler with a good amount of content. It has secrets, upgrades, and different classes to try out. The expansion pack seems excessively difficult (the first boss seems almost unbeatable and is not fun at all, regardless), but the xpack is free and the base campaign is quite good.I only played single player, and I'd recommend that anyone doing so start with a ranged class. Melee is clearly designed for multiplayer, and I found it incredibly difficult to solo as melee.

Posted: October 7, 2015
												I'd love to put more time into this game.  It's a great multiplayer dungeon crawler.  There are tons of secrets to be discovered.  My favorite is a puzzle that unlocks a bonus round.Each class has a distinct feel and playstyle.  Just to name a few, there's the glass cannon wizard, a high HP life-draining warlock, and a ranger - the master of ranged combat.  As you continue through the duengons, you can unlock new abilities.  Don't be put off by the warlock's starting puny dagger.  Eventually the warlock can cast devastating spells.  Just seeing what each class can do is enough to make me want to dive back into the dungeons.Since you share lives with the team (unless something changed since my last login,) it can be difficult if you have reckless teammates.  Although, when the lives runout the next player to die is essentially sidelined.  I've had some players drop the game after that, but it is possible to get more lives and resurrect dead teammates.If you're looking for an inexpensive game to play with friends, Hammerwatch is good option with a decent learning curve.  If nothing else, wishlist it and wait until the next steam sale.

Posted: December 19, 2015

Worth $10 and if it goes on sale (which it will like all games) then it is basically your civic duty to buy this game. Posted: December 26, 2014
												It definitely plays a lot like 8bit Gauntlet, which was clearly the developer's intention given that the bonus stages are taken right out of 8bit Gauntlet, but significantly fleshed out. They've nixed that game's 'food' life bar, thankfully, and added RPG elements to let you improve your damage, range, dmg mitigation, regen, etc. You "save keys to open doors," though here there are 3 different color keys to open their respective doors. Collect treasure to purchase your upgrades from vendors. Loot is shared and one class is a healer, so cooperation is easier done here than in 8bit Gauntlet. There are also boss fights along the way. The art is nice, adding variety to levels and enemies while still evoking a sense of retro gaming. Additionally, you can change the parameters. Play with limited or infinite lives, for example, so you can scale the game to a difficulty level that suits you. Essentially, any thought you might have had along the lines of, "You know, I liked Gauntlet as a kid... but I wish they had added XYZ," that XYZ is probably in Hammerwatch.

Posted: December 26, 2014
												A game to be playing with a couple of friends :)It can be loads of fun when the teamwork really kicks in, but it can also be frustrating to play, especially if you miss an essential key and have to go back and hunt for it, or if you end up pairing up with a troll or two who ignores the teamplay aspects of the game and just rushes ahead in order to claim "victory" (It is a teamgame, and personal score has no practical meaning, even though it can be accessed in the post game statistics).Main pros:Allows you to team up with a couple of friendsContains small simple puzzles which allows for more gold => more improvements at the shopsHas a lot of small secrets which can be found by breaking walls and playing right6 different classes: priest, paladin, warlock, mage, thief and ranger, with different attacks, healths, upgrade costs, abilities, attack speed etc.A couple of different play modes (both campaign and a TD like version)different difficulty levels, which allows you to try out the main elements on easy and get the hang of the basic game before rushing into difficulties more demanding of the players (faster and stronger monsters + more expensive upgrades).Main cons:There is no save function in a multiplayer game (and the game contains various bonus lvl's and 12 floors as well as bosses etc.), which can make it an ordeal to get through since it has to be done in one goGraphics are very simple, but then again for the nostalgic persons out there this might be on the con side, as it does take you back to some of the early games :)Trolls may join your game if you forget to make it private (and therefore just lose your precious ankhs etc. before you get a chance to kick them).All in all an easy going game, with a number of tricks and secrets which can greatly improve your gameplay.Because of the fun that I have had with a couple of friends during a couple of run throughs, but that and the chance of finding secret compartments are the main strengths of the game. As a single player game I personally found it to be less interesting as the game experience IMO needs to be shared with a couple of friends :)For fans of the genre I would recommend this game, for more general players I would deem it an ok teamgame, but not and exceptional one.

Posted: December 26, 2014
												This is an incredible game. I started a 2 man co-op game with my little brother, and we're hooked two hours in. The mechanics are fresh and interesting, and the graphics are a homage to retro gamers like myself. When fighting the Queen for the first time, my little brother said:"This is pixellated Dark Souls. That's how insane this is."I haven't tried it single-player, but I can tell you right now this game wouldn't be as fun without the co-op experience. You can go in hacking and slashing and hoping for the best, or you can form a strategy with your team. This is easily one of the best co-op games I've played in a while.

Posted: December 28, 2014
												Amazing. If you like rogue-likes or diablo-esque games, this one is for you. The only downside is the graphics are SNES-like and that may not appeal to some people. I personally like the art and it gives it a nice feel, but to each their own. You can control three melees, Paladin, Rogue, Warlock and three ranged, Archer, Mage and Cleric. None of these classes are required to beat any of the game maps, but Cleric certainly helps in team-play, and Archer is quite honestly OP if you are having trouble and need something to help you. The game comes with around 4 or 5 maps, iirc. Depending on your skill and how many you play with, each map lasts around an hour or so. But it's got way more than 5hours of content. Steam workshop integration saves the day. With the map editor in the game, people are able to easily (presumably, I haven't tried to make a map, sorry) make maps for you to download and try. One of the top rated maps alone will last you over 3 hours, Hexed is quite a long and well made map with hard monsters and good puzzles. If you are playing solo, you might wanna pull out that ranger, but you can have fun with the game as any class. In a group however, the game becomes even more fun. You can all pick the same character if you wish, no class locks like Gauntlet or other similar games. If this appeals to you, pick it up.

												Totally delivers on the classic Guantlet feel. Possibly better than original Guantlet did!Pros: Fun times. Good challenge. Pixels done right. Surprisingly good-attitude among the players. Pretty well-fleshed out content-wise, with the classes, skills, enemies, shops, secrets... Crutches and challenges are simple, but make for some lol-able replay. Speaking of replayability, yes, it's got it - via those secrets and challenges for solo, and multiplied by randomness of multiplayer.Cons: Auto-fire isn't - pressing one button really fast is not a skill, it's not fun, it's medically damaging - ow ow ow make it stop. If you don't have an analog joystick, trying to work with 4 directions is ... extra hard and slightly less fun.

Posted: December 7, 2014
												Hammerwatch is a lot of fun with friends, and has a surprising amount of depth for a dungeon crawler with no random elements. One of my personal issues with the game is the lack of creativity with the classes. The depth mentioned earlier is not present with the classes, some examples being "Wizard" and "Paladin". Even with the lame class options, there is some really nice synergy with some pals. I don't know about other people, but I know people who always pick certain classes in RPG's, personally I prefer Mages and Wizards. If you have friends like these, then buying the four-pack of Hammerwatch and plowing through the game over a weekend is one of the best experiences I can imagine. Otherwise, I'd say pass on the game, because single-player isn't great. 8.5/10, multiplayer is fun as hell.

Posted: December 1, 2014
												I *highly* recommend this game for people that like oldschool RPG/Hack N Slash genre style games. You play from a top down perspective and kill as many enemies as it takes to get to the end of each level. It feels much like the old gauntlet games. You eat food/crystals to regen health or mana, gain money to upgrade your spells and abilites, and uncover in-game secrets for a chance at great rewards. You can play as a Paladin, Priest, Rogue, Warlock, Archer, or a Wizard. Levels are always the same layout each new game, but with plenty of classes and a lengthy compaign it does not disapoint as far as value goes. You can easily expect 15-25+ hours with both campaigns put together, so if you manage to find this on sale its a no-brainer as far as value is concerned. With Survival mode and plenty of workshop maps to play this game can provide even more hours. I have seen people hit around 30-80 hours before growing bored of this game.---- However, it can get slightly repetitive after long play sessions and the graphics are not exactly cutting edge. Directional targeting can be tricky as well. Online play can be a little frustrating, as people will just kick you for slight mistakes or at their convenience. (Whether you deserved it or if they just wanted to have some fun for kicking you) I suggest you host your own game if thats the case, and just let people join you. I only prefer this game with a xbox controller or equivalent gamepad in mind. PC controls get the job done though if you dont have a choice, the PC controls didnt seem like they were a huge inconvience.

Even if you beat the two maps currently in the game you can download more maps from steam and even create your own. However this is a multiplayer game and while the single player is fun, I recommend this more to people who plan to play this with friends.

Posted: December 20, 2014
												I literally just purchased this (because at $1.50 why not?). I am not even an overt fanatic of dungeon-crawls or 8-bit aesthetic. But at just two hours in I know I'm going to be putting a lot more into it. Controls are incredibly smooth, the visual and audio are slick and charming. The maps are massive without being too tedious (and a great map overlay helps a lot). The beginning is calm, allowing you to learn the game without any obnoxious tutorials. Then the difficulty rachets up noticably. By the time I arrived at the first boss I was already forty five minutes past how long I had intended to play. The battle was tense, and chaotic, without seeming unfair (all mistakes were my mistakes, no ridiculous glitches). I beat the boss with two hit points left, swearing up a storm, and when I realized I was victorious I performed the first involuntary fist pump I've done while playing a video game since I don't know when. I would easily have bought this game for full price (or double the full price). I can't recommend it enough.

Posted: December 20, 2014
												This is *almost* a great game.I really want to be able to recommend it, but it could benefit from a few tweaks to improve the pacing and excitement of the game.For starters, the levels are long and back-tracky. Monsters don't regenerate, so backtracking is a boring trek. Health restores are sparesely laid out - they're adequate in number, but backtracking to the last health location is boring. There is no reward for playing aggressively, and playing cautiously is... boring. Also, there is little visual feedback on leveling up, and attack/alt-attack options are nil. Lastly, the controls are poorly mapped, and the game would be a lot better as a twin-stick shooter (like Hotline Miami) rather than the current strafe/lock mechanic.I had fun playing it, but Hammerwatch ended up being a fun diversion rather than something memorable, which it could easily have been with some tightening up of mechanics and level layout.Get it when it's on sale, but it's not the New Best Thing (or even Retro Best Thing), which it could have been.

												Hammerwatch is a pretty simple action adventure. You can buy improvements for you charakter like increased HP, MP ATK and so on, but you have to stick to the wappons you already have. Its not comparable with games like Borderlands or Diablo, where you try to find better equipment.The big advantage was that you could configure it to have infinite lives. Normaly I don't chose such an option, but that way I was able to talk my wife into playing this game with me.She played the archer which is god for taking out static enemies with distance weapons, like the freezing turrets or the plants who attack you throug the holes on the ground. I've played the warlock. But I have to admit, the warlock gets a bit overpowered at the end.I enjoyed playing the game. Maybe I can win my wife to play the add-onn with me too. ^^

Posted: February 25, 2014
												On Mac OS X there are serious issues with this game. On boot up I noticed two immediate issues. Firstly, you cannot quit the game. That's right. It crashes. This is made worse when in fullscreen mode as sometimes not even the 'Force Quit' option works. To sort of resolve this, I had to put the resolution to 'Windowed mode' and exiting has to be done by the red X in the top left corner of the window (usually still accompanied with a Force Quit to finish off). The second issue I found seems to be an issue with Steam - when attempting to view the in game map (press Tab) the map and game is replaced with heavy block textures, the game is still working but it is unplayable in this state. Once entered, the only thing you can do is... Yep. Force Quit. This does have a sort of temporary fix. In Preference>In-Game you must untick the 'enable the steam overlay' button. So you can play the game. Just not on steam. Sort of defeats the point. What is worse is I couldn't find any information from the developers on if they are even doing anything about these game crippling bugs. I hope they are. This game looks fun. Wish I could play it :(

Posted: December 31, 2014
												When I first played Hammerwatch I found the non-regenerating health to be a big barrier to fun.  I started somewhat casually and eventually I ended up getting stuck and unable to continue due to the fixed checkpoints and limited resources.  Starting over and taking the game much more seriously was my only option.However, then I discovered the difficulty settings that allow you to customize all that.  Regenerating health, regenerating mana, extra lives, etc...  With just some regenerating health it was all of a sudden a great casual action RPG without requiring every battle to be won with minimal casualties.  I really enjoyed the tactical options the various classes and powers provide.  This is definitely not a brainless button masher where you charge in and lay waste to all around you.  That gets you killed.  Even with regenerating health.Three player local co-op was awesome, as it broadens the available roles and powers.My biggest complaint, other than the default difficulty level, is that we would occasionally get stuck and have no idea how to proceed.  You sometimes have to traverse through old empty levels looking for a button you missed, or a new secret passage that opened.  This was super boring.  A zoomable map that highlighted plot objectives (it need not reveal new secret areas that open up) would have solved that.

Posted: December 31, 2014
Hammerwatch is a 2D, rouge-like, co-op, dungeon crawler game. The game can be played both 4player locally or via the internet. Controllers are also supported.The game currently offers two campaigns, one main story and one side quest, plus two extra game modes, called survival and defense. You choose to play as different classes, each with it's own set of skills. The current classes are Paladin, Wizard, Ranger, Warlock, Thief and Priest.On keyboard, you walk with WASD and attack with the arrow keys, with the primary attack Up and your first special with Left (which consumes mana). You strafe with Space and "hold" with LShift. All controls are rebindable.The games controls are good once you get used to them. If you didn't notice from the logo, pictures and video, the game has pixel graphics, but has some special effects, such as nice faded light from torches. The options are fine, and my only problem with it is that you cannot change the resolution if you play in fullscreen, however it shouldn't be a problem for the majority of the players.In the main campaign you start off right after a bridge collapsed and your NPC friends on the other side tell you to continue without them. You start of by fighting some bats, and you can destroy some crates with a chance of getting extra gold which also lies spread out in the map. Gold is shared in an interesting way, where if one player picks up 2 gold, all players get 2 gold. However if one player buys an upgrade for 200 gold, only that player looses 200 gold and no one else. The gameplay is good, and with friends to back you up the game gets way more exciting, which also makes this game a great game to play if you have an extra keyboard/controller laying around. You start off with 2 lives, or re-spawns, per player, and if you die, you obviously loose one life. There is a shop where you can buy extra lives. You can also buy upgrades for your character, varying from health upgrades to higher damage and defense to health pots. At the end of each level you fight a boss.For the ones who want more of a challenge there are modifiers to disable mana regeneration, disable hp pickups, only 1 hp, etc. And for the less skilled there are modifiers to give you hp regen, infinite or double lives, "5x mana regen", and a few more.Final thoughs: My only problem with the gameplay is that the game gets repetitive. You fight the same enemies the entire first floor, and could be generalized as a common weak enemy, a slightly less-common stronger enemy, a somewhat rare strong enemy and one mini-boss. This does not mean that the game itself is boring, only that I at the third level saw the same pattern for each level.However I have gotten many fun hours from this game, both when I play by my self and with friends. Everything above should explain enough why I really like this game.As an extra note, I bought this game early on, and the game was very fun back then, but oh my, how the game has improved with each update. The menu system, new characters, a new campaign, new secrets and some extra tweaks show how the developers have worked hard to make the game better since day one. They have my support!

Posted: December 31, 2014
												In 2009, Hammer Watching Simulator 2009 was THE game to have. The venues that one could use to watch hammers were nigh countless. Picnic benches, beaches, tool sheds, you name it. The types of hammers available for watching were also commendable. Basic metal hammers, ball hammers, jackhammers, mallets, electric hammers, your pretty standard fare. The graphics were great, and the controls allowed one to jump between gazing, staring, and watching all with the click of a mouse. All in all, it was a benchmark in home hardware observation simulation technology.Suffice to say, this game is not a worthy sequel.

Posted: December 20, 2014
												I'm giving this a thumbs-up where other reviewers gave it a down.  I got this from a humblebundle and wasn't focused on this at all.  After trying it out I was surprised.  The best part, I got my wife to play it and it's the first game (besides minecraft) she's enjoyed co-op enough to pick this game.  Usually she has me pick the games we play together.Overall I enjoy this game.  There are several problems that stand out to me and I wanted to mention:- The campaign maps aren't always straight forward.  Several times we've cleared an area and forgot where we need to go.  This causes you to walk a lot exploring for enemies.  (That's usually what kills a co-op session with my wife)- The Paladin is a well rounded, powerful class.  Had I known he unlocks a healing spell, my wife and I would be Paladin+Paladin instead of Paladin+Priest.- Although this is minor and very subjective... I'm not a fan of the money system for upgrades.  I would have preferred a skill tree so I could see what I'm aiming for.  Instead I looked up the skills on the wiki to create an upgrade plan.- Co-op is a requirement to fully enjoy this game.Finally I'd like to address one comment I've seen in a couple other reviews.+ Although the campaign is linear (not random or procedural), I've found that the replay-ability is fairly high because of both the diverse classes and the amount of secret areas in maps.

												Disclaimer: I play this game at the easy difficulty.ProsThis game is actually a lot of fun. At the easy difficulty level it's really friendly / casual and should be doable for people who just want to have fun without frustration.The levels are easy to navigate thanks to a very useful map. You can show the map on screen and still continue to play. So, it's easy to see where to go next.The upgrades are actually useful and give you a sense of progress.There are ample save game spots, so you can stop whenever you have to (if you have little spare time to game).You can quite easily get more/extra lifes.  I so far haven't died often enough to actually have no more lifes left, so for me it's great. You can even buy lifes quite cheaply, but that means you have less money to spend on upgrades.ConsThe settings aren't remembered. So, every time you restart the game you have to rebind the controls again. This is an incredibly annoying bug.I would have preferred a little bit more variety in both the levels and the enemies.The puzzles are so easy that you can hardly call them puzzles. A bit more difficulty here would have been a welcome change of pace.So far (3.8 hours into the game) I died 4 times. Once on the first boss, and 3 times on spiketraps. Whenever you accidentally hit a spiketrap you die immediately (instead of losing health). This is not fun, it makes for cheap deaths.The graphics are serviceable, but not really all that great.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes Gauntlet-style games. I've had a ton of fun playing through the campaigns with friends, and we're still making our way through the great community campaigns available in the Steam Marketplace!The party-creation experience could be easier and more consistent than it is, but once you get into a game with your buddies, the fun is immediate and sustained. The various classes and available modifiers offer lots of opportunity for experimenting with different strategies, which helps to keep things fresh even after you've completed several campaigns with the same group of people.Note that while the game is playable with a keyboard all of my friends and I prefer playing this with controllers to reduce hand fatigue. We use PS3 and Xbox 360 controllers, but you can use the controller of your choice.

Posted: March 17, 2015
												This game was a slow starter for me, but no less than the third time trying to get into it, it hooked me hard. I think all it took was finding the right class, as the Wizard didn't really do it for me the first two times I played.The Ranger was fast, long range, and did good damage. I loved the playthrough on this class!The game ramped up slowly and had quite a lot of mindless killing, but as I progressed through the dungeons, the difficulty curved up pretty significantly. By the last act I was on the edge of my seat, pulling off moves and combos that skyrocketed the fun level to great heights.This is a *fantastic* game. If you can put up with some repetitive killing, you'll find that the levels, secrets, difficulty and visuals are all top notch and there is a TON of fun to be had for the price. Play on hard. The enemies are faster and it makes it a much more intense experience.

												I am a sucker for rogue-likes and dungeon-crawlers. I suppose it carries a small piece of nostalgic bliss with it. From my days of playing the orginal Rogue and Gauntlet, Hammerwatch is a nice refresher on a similar style of game. I love that it actually has couch co-op allowing myself and the girlfriend to spend and evening just smashing that attack button while building up super combos and accidently running into secrets. Overall, if you're hunting for a story, this isn't for you. Why? Because there isn't a story. It's a blank slate. If you are so inclined maybe you could make up a story as you bash through swarms of baddies. Give your little pixel man a voice and hum on through the death that awaits you. Becasue you will die, friend.  That's why there's upgrade though. Become all powerful and stop that pesky dying stuff. Be the champion you've always wanted to be.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												AMAZING!I've been playing PC games for 15+ years and I am not going to lie, I am a HUGE graphics junky, I'm pretty picky when it comes to them. Hammerwatch is a step back into the classic top view DOS graphic game world. When I was younger I'd always play a PC game called Gladiator and GOT (God of Thunder) if you liked either of those, then this game will be a hit. I've played quite a few hours of Hammerwatch so far and honestly playing it Multiplayer was the most fun I've had in a long time. It's a very simple control scheme that is easy to master, however, the game itself has some challenging parts. I've been playing the campaign with my Non-Nerdy girlfriend and for the first time in her life I heard her say the words "I can't wait to upgrade my mana..." Granted I'm not a Magic User type of player, however that brought tears to my eyes. Hammerwatch has a strong level editor and there are few to no complaints about anything in this game. I picked it up for $2.00 on sale and immediately bought a few more copies for close friends and family. If I would have played it before for the sales, I would of paid the $10.00 asking price. The classes of characters are well designed each with their own perks, they vary greatly in attributes and the feeling reminds me of a MMORPG Raid group where you have Tanks, Healers, Ranged, etc. I highly suggest Hammerwatch to anybody looking for a quick jump in, low requirements yet addicting game.

												Edited for the new update:Do you like kiting? Do you like when all the challenge comes from that alone? Then this is the game for you. With the new expansion pack update, you'll be kiting in no time when playing on Medium or Hard mode. Adding even more repetitive fights than the main game, you'll get to kite to your hearts content.Don't worry. The graphics are still good and the game is probably fun in co-op because another part of the challenge in higher difficulties is the time it takes to kill the monsters - in co-op, it takes a lot less.If you are into games that have repetitive elements, slow progression, unrewarding gameplay, good graphics, soundtrack and otherwise good gameplay (if it was more balanced), you'll like this game. At the end after having grinded a LOT you'll probably have fun playing the game because you can finally fight the monsters at a faster pace.8/10 - The soundtrack and game setting is just that good. Especially the soundtrack.

Posted: January 21, 2015
												"Beat" the first campaign and reached the first boss of the second campaign. This game is not worth the time or effort. It is a gauntlet clone that brings absolutely nothing to the table except for unfair challenges and frustration. My major complaints are the following: 1. I played as a Ranger first time through the first campaign, and then tried the other classes. The range advantage of the ranger is so ridiculously great that it is utterly pointless to play as anyone but them. Challenges that are harrowing and ridiculously frustrating to anyone else are easily exploited by the ranger, who can shoot up everything including enemy spawners before they have time to retaliate. 2. After sinking 11+ hours into beating the first campaign, I beat the final boss and was rewarded with a punishing bad end because I didn't collect 12 planks of fracking wood. The feeling of destroying a colossal dragon only to be rewarded with death because of a low lumber supply is unbelievably dissapointing. I feel robbed of my victory and my time. 3. The second campaign is a much more interesting setting - too bad I won't be able to see any of it because the sand shark fight is the most impossible garbage i've ever encountered. The fact that they only have a split second window of vulnerability would be enough. The fact that the ground beneath your feet is constantly shifting would be enough. But once you figure out a pattern to survive the fight, the monsters actually stop FREAKING ATTACKING YOU, and just buzz around the arena wasting your time and energy. I spent over an hour on one attempt of this fight, simply because the damn things wouldn't show their faces so i could hit them. The encounter literally just sits on its butt and waits for you to screw up and get caught in a sand trap or something long enough to kill you in 3-4 hits while you're trying to claw your way out. All in all this game was a humongous waste of time and showed nothing but frustration and dissapointment time and again. I haven't played such a horribly unsatisfying game in a long time.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												A great retro RPG with some clever puzzles and fun but basic combat that is somewhat lacking in depth, with the base moves not really changing much throughout. However, this game really shines when you bring your mates along for the ride. Coop with 1-3 others either on the couch or online is a huge amount of fun and you'll have to work together well to survive, particularly in the more difficult expansion campaign.Highly recommended to play with friends, perhaps less so by yourself although still worth the price of admission in my opinion.I would also recommend playing with a controller rather than a keyboard if you have one available, it makes strafing and combat in general MUCH easier.

Posted: December 10, 2014
												Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ there is something about this game, i can't put my finger on it, but it has been one of my favorites, and my friends favorites ARPG games of 2014. The game is fast paced, unforgiving, and exciting, it has the oldschool type graphics, sounds, and gameplay and it stays true to it. The combat is amazing, charging through hordes and hordes of enemies, looting thousands of gold pieces and buying new and exciting spells. The game is definitely meant to be played with friends however. There is a steam workshop for community maps, which add infinite amount of replayability, there are 2 different campaign modes,  a tower defence and a survival mode as well. the game is just addicting to play, to watch enemies explode in your wake. I would give the game a 10/10 just for gameplay, however, the single player campaign could use a bit more story and organization to it (the desert campaign does well however). Overall 9/10

Posted: December 25, 2014
												Hammerwatch is game which can be called as a hybrid of hack and slash with an RPG. Set within a pixelated fantasy world, this little dungeon crawler is deeper than it can appear at the first glance, and will keep the player occupied, if not entertained, for many hours with hordes of baddies waiting to be chopped, zapped, pierced by arrows and fooled into the intricate (or not really) traps which the game's environment is full of.The plotline of the original Hammerwatch(for those people reading the review in hope of seeing the complete picture, i apologize, i haven't played the expansion) appears to be simple, even somewhat casual - Heroes arrive into Castle Hammerwatch (hence the name of the game) for reasons unknown. Once there, the bridge suddenly collapses, leaving either one or several of the tiny adventurers (depending on whether you chose to indulge yourself in single or multiplayer experience) no other choice but to press forward, towards the glorious fate of a true champion... or champions. The plotline, in any case, is the least important aspect of such a game, and the simplicity of your quest (whichever that may be) only strengthens the pursuit for gold, glory and an epic end boss battle. The original idea here is that unlike in some other well known dungeon crawlers, in Hammerwatch you actually proceed from the lowest levels to the higher ones, since you are raiding and pillaging a castle tower, instead of delving into the burning hells or some other nasty, forsaken place... There are, to the best of my memory, 6 classes to choose from, starting from a valiant paladin which can chop the undead as if they were lettuce, and ending with mages and priests which can boil the undead as if they were... well, uh, lettuce. Speaking of the enemies, in Hammerwatch, you will encounter lots of different variations of Eevil, most of which also have some kind of a ridiculous looking spawning point, akin to a huge, immobile eye, or a pit full of bones. Your player character, throughout his noble struggles against badness, will be able to (and will have to) obtain all sorts of upgrades from hidden vendors which opened up shop in not the most fitting place, trading in turn gold which you will find generously scattered all over by some jolly chap, perhaps a leprechaun of Santa or some other clown who accidentally found himself lost in the grim halls of this confounded place. If it wouldn't be for the upgrades which gradually bolster the characters stats and expand his spells and abilities, i honestly would have no right to attribute this game as an RPG, but luckily, each class has 3 or 4 different abilities or spells, and this makes the playing process a bit more diverse and developed. The interface is very simple, and for this type of a mainly arcade game, i suppose it's the way it should be, but seeing more pixelated icons of swords and armor and trinkets and such would have been nice... Instead, we have a plain and simple text when it comes to improving your armor or attack parameters. The pixel graphics of this game were drawn with excellence, and the environment around your tiny protagonist, as well as the little guy (or gal) him/her self, make you believe that this little world is alive. The credit for this also goes out to the fine soundtrack, which was obviously done by individuals who know how to make music for fantasy games. While being simple and ambient, it nonetheless shifts the player into the straightforward world of Hammerwatch, where slicing countless minions of an unknown enemy which awaits on the topmost floor of the castle is as ordinary as eating a muffin or taking a dog out for a walk. In truth, Hammerwatch is a fun, action filled game which is great to play along with other companions, luckily such an opportunity is always possible because there are always some people on the servers. The game brings you back to the old days, to the days of The Gauntlet and whatnot, and i can only recommend it. It has good, original pixel graphics, an original, although a bit too simple gameplay, and is well worth the time and your money.Oh, and lest i forget... On your adventure in the castle, keep being on a lookout for strange planks, you will seriously need them ;)
